newsitem.title: UK: FROM THE FLIGHTDECK - The Air Cargo Week In Review.
newsitem.headline: FROM THE FLIGHTDECK - The Air Cargo Week In Review.

text.p: This is Reuters' look back at the major developments in the global air cargo industry in the week October 4 - October 11.
**OCTOBER 4**
ZURICH - Swissair says cargo shipments transported in the first eight months of 1996 totalled 1.05 billion FTKs, up 6.4 percent on the same period 1995.
NAPLES - Prime minister Romano Prodi says he had asked France to help Italy's bid to join the Airbus consortium.
HONG KONG - Hong Kong's civil aviation department says it turning down applications from airlines seeking an average of 150 extra flights a week in and out of the territory's Kai Tak airport.
LUXEMBOURG - Officials says the EC is planning to allow airlines to buy and sell their landing and take-off slots at EU airports but will not introduce wholesale auctions of all slots.
HONG KONG - EVA Air says that its air cargo market share on the new Hong Kong to Taipei route "has been as high as 20 percent".

AMSTERDAM - Koninklijke PTT Netherland says it would cooperate with an Australian investigation into possible insider trading of TNT options, but did not expect any of its employees to have been involved.
LONDON - BA says it welcomed the prospect of European backing for the legalised, commercial trade of airport take-off and landing slots.
TORONTO - Air Canada and SAS says they agreed to develop a comprehensive air travel alliance that may include code-sharing.
PARIS - Le Monde reported the French government wants to create an airline by bringing together privately-owned Euralair and AOM and buying up the insolvent Air Liberte, to keep out BA.
BRUSSELS - AEA says global freight traffic carried by West European airlines in August 1996 was up seven percent on the same month last year at 1.87 billion FTKs'.
* AEA says global freight traffic carried by West European airlines in the first eight months of 1996 up was 4.1 percent against the same period 1995.
PARIS - Tunis Air says it plans to launch a four-time weekly Boeing 737-200 freighter service between Paris and Tunis later this month or early November in partnership with Air France.

ZURICH - Airport authority figures show global cargo traffic handled at Zurich airport in the first eight months of 1996 totalled 287,616 tonnes, a decreased of 1.4 percent on the same period last year.
HANOVER - A senior AEA executive says regional airlines face the possible loss of airport slots, addition costs and increased passenger liability under proposed EU transport rules.
* The European Regional Airlines Association (ERA) says it has decided to change its name to the European Regions Airlines Association.
LONDON - BA public relations manager Michael Blunt says it welcomed the prospect of European backing for the legalised, commercial trade of airport take-off and landing slots.
MADRID - Portuguese airport authority ANA says cargo traffic at Lisbon airport rose 1.9 percent in September to 8,405 tonnes.
SEATTLE - Boeing says it delivered 54 commercial jet airlines in the third quarter ended September 30.
ABIDJAN - A company official says troubled price-cutting French charter company Air Liberte is to suspend its flights from France to Ivory Coast from October 5.

LONDON - BA says it has asked Europe's transport and competition commissioners to block "with utmost urgency" a bid by French regional airline AOM to buy its competitor Air Liberte, which is in receivership.
LONG BEACH - A report published by McDonnell Douglas Corp says the world's passenger jet fleet will need to double in the coming years, adding 13,600 aircraft worth an estimated $5.1 trillion.
LONDON - Emirates says it will be launching new services to Kuala Lumpur and Sanaa on October 27 and 28 respectively.
* Emirates says it will increase weekly flights to Nairobi and Jakarta from October 27, when the airline commences its winter schedule.
PARIS - The national pilots union SNPL says pilots at BA's French associate airline TAT, ended their strike.
ATLANTA - ValuJet says it had sold 15 surplus DC-9 and MD-80 aircraft and five engines, enabling the company to retire $46.6 million of aircraft bank debt.

WASHINGTON - The U.S. transportation department says it tentatively approved a carrier agreement waiving a liability limit for passengers and their families in the event of death or injury on international flights.
